commit_message:
Xen: Remove extraneous logging of type information

There doesn't appear to be any value in logging the type of vdi_rec
after its value has just been logged.  It's just adding noise to the
logs.

Change-Id: Ia5ccc634375d9a4fa4783487908cb4f91f435a68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/102908/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add downgrade case to pending release checking

We have to make possible to downgrade openstack release from
later version to earlier version.

Implements blueprint openstack-patching-nailgun-part

Change-Id: I473887ae49f9fa85e2cafcc53cb23cc230e321cc

added_lines: def test_pending_release_validation_success(self): curr_release = Mock( id=1, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.1', can_update_from_versions=[], ) pend_release = Mock( id=2, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.2', can_update_from_versions=['2014.1'], ) self.assertTrue( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( curr_release, curr_release ) ) self.assertTrue( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( curr_release, pend_release ) ) self.assertTrue( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( pend_release, curr_release ) ) def test_pending_release_validation_unsuccess(self): curr_release = Mock( id=1, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.1', can_update_from_versions=[], ) pend_release = Mock( id=2, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.2', can_update_from_versions=[], ) self.assertFalse( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( curr_release, pend_release ) ) pend_release = Mock( id=2, operating_system='CentOS', version='2014.2', can_update_from_versions=['2014.1'], ) self.assertFalse( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( curr_release, pend_release ) ) curr_release = Mock( id=1, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.1', can_update_from_versions=[], ) pend_release = Mock( id=2, operating_system='Ubuntu', version='2014.2', can_update_from_versions=['2014.0'], ) self.assertFalse( ClusterValidator._can_be_updated_curr_release_with_pend_release( pend_release, curr_release ) )

commit_message:
Relax requirement for tenant_name in get_auth()

get_auth() in client.py raises an exception if
tenant_name is not included in the os_options
dict. This is overly constrained since tenant_id
is equally sufficient. This patch modifies
get_auth to require either tenant_name
or tenant_id.

Change-Id: Ibbcda1704637eb887efa5895579d260a1e072327
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/53/94353/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not ('tenant_name' in os_options or 'tenant_id' in os_options):
deleted_lines: if (not 'tenant_name' in os_options):

commit_message:
Update ci scripts

Changes:
Fix multibackend job be multibackend indeed.
Increase amount of threads to run tempest with, after increase of
volume group capacity for Cinder, that is used by generic driver.

Partially-implements blueprint multibackend-installation-tempest-job

Change-Id: Ia7aada6c29d4c2a4929384e9e03057b3cccc470d

commit_message:
Change olso.config to be installed from pypi instead of tarballs.o.o

* For legacy reason, we pulled oslo.config from tarballs.o.o since
  that's where newer releases existed.  But pypi now has the
  versions we need.

Closes-Bug: #1334891
Change-Id: Ic366f47bfa771eba18bb6b3a7694b1edd9aed177
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/74/102974/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pip install extras oslo.config>=1.2.0 python-novaclient python-swiftclient python-cinderclient kombu>2.4.7 six babel python-heatclient passlib jinja2
deleted_lines: # install oslo.config from source than pypi (which is older) pip install http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3 pip install extras python-novaclient python-swiftclient python-cinderclient kombu>2.4.7 six babel python-heatclient passlib jinja2

Introduces a new conf value called allowed_resize_options which

Change-Id: Iead3876e470130aed06b097745fae5464b10bfb7
'}]
commit_message:
Allow resize options to be conditionally turned off

Introduces a new conf value called allowed_resize_options which
specifies the list of allowable values for the resize action on
instances. It is a ListOpt which supports values of volume, and
flavorRef.

Change-Id: Iead3876e470130aed06b097745fae5464b10bfb7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/60/102660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if key in body['resize'] and key in CONF.allowed_resize_options: if not selected_option: return wsgi.Result(None, 501) else: return selected_option(instance, args)
deleted_lines: if key in body['resize']: return selected_option(instance, args)

commit_message:
Unifies how BadStoreUri gets raised and logged

Refactoring store code to raise BadStoreUri in unified way.

Changes BadStoreUri messages being logged as info from debug.

Fixes translations accordingly.

Ensures no URI's nor credentials logged with these messages.

Closes bug #1287506

Change-Id: I246885d68b0af9e91ede48aaa2b1e6849e5b3b3d

added_lines: raise exception.BadStoreUri(message=reason) raise exception.BadStoreUri(message=reason) reason = ('HTTP request returned a %(status)s status code.' LOG.debug(reason) raise exception.BadStoreUri(message=reason) reason = ("The HTTP URL %(path)s attempted to redirect " LOG.debug(reason) raise exception.BadStoreUri(message=reason)
deleted_lines: raise exception.BadStoreUri(reason) raise exception.BadStoreUri(reason) msg = ('HTTP request returned a %(status)s status code.' LOG.debug(msg) raise exception.BadStoreUri(msg) msg = ("The HTTP URL %(path)s attempted to redirect " LOG.debug(msg) raise exception.BadStoreUri(msg)

commit_message:
Added removable drives in user installation dialog

This patch is to avoid missing hard drives which
are present but are marked as removable.

Change-Id: If2524b3dff36703e42fb46da2bd042b3ac63f681
Closes-Bug: #1290933
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/83/79683/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: removable_drives="" d=`echo ${drv} | sed -e 's/!/\//'` else removable_drives="${removable_drives} ${d}"set ${drives} ${removable_drives} echo '****************************************************************' echo '* W A R N I N G *' echo '* *' echo '* Which of the detected hard drives do you want to be used as *' echo '* installation target? *' echo '* *' echo '****************************************************************' echo "Possible choices:" echo "Persistent drives: ${drives}" echo "Removable drives: ${removable_drives}" for drive in ${drives[@]} ${removable_drives[@]}; do tgtdrive=`echo ${drives} ${removable_drives} | sed -e "s/^\s*//" -e "s/\s*$//"`
deleted_lines: d=`echo ${drv} | sed -e 's/!/\//'`set ${drives} echo '********************************************************************************' echo '* W A R N I N G *' echo '* *' echo '* Which of the detected hard drives do you want to be used as *' echo '* installation target? *' echo '* *' echo '********************************************************************************' echo "Possible choices: ${drives}" for drive in ${drives[@]}; do tgtdrive=`echo ${drives} | sed -e "s/^\s*//" -e "s/\s*$//"`

commit_message:
introduce $SYSTEMD_SYSTEM_UNIT_DIR

export $SYSTEMD_SYSTEM_UNIT_DIR to know where .service files should be
moved.
So far those files are moved directly in /usr/lib/systemd/system whereas
Debian use /lib/systemd/system.

We load the value from the systemd pkg-config file.

The patch don't use pkg-config directly for three reasons:
 - environment.d files are run before install.d and the other similar
 targets, making hard to install an additional dependency
 - the .pc file can easily be parsed using awk
 - pkg-config package name is not standard across the different
 supported distributions

$SYSTEMD_SYSTEM_UNIT_DIR default value is /lib because, as pointed by James
Slagle, /lib is actually a symlink to /usr/lib/ on Fedora and will work
for Debian and Fedora.

See: https://bugs.debian.org/719634

Change-Id: I413a92284e6a79e7fcdde99c5138bc3ce8e85e80

commit_message:
Set glance protocol and port as Heat configurable

This change is to set the glance protocol and port as
configurable via the Heat template. Presently the port is
hard-coded in the elements nova.conf file, and the protocol
is assumed as being the default (http).

This change will allow the glance_api_servers
to be set (in nova.conf) using the constituent parts:
    glance_protocol://glance_host:glance_port

Change to nova.conf to read this value is:
    Idccc0d60c9f6b17a853c6de1bbea64bfc7e028b2

Default port value is set to the nova default(9292) which is
currently hard-coded in the elements nova.conf file.
Default protocol value is set to the nova default(http).

Change-Id: I3c7218292797c62c36e2aaab4f325bf053ef140b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/81/85081/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Store seed details in the JSON

To bring the seed in line with nodes, we should also store its
pertinant details in the JSON file as well.

Change-Id: Ibeefa495478f8d64207476a8cb46c4e3af2c2e8b

commit_message:
Make use of the seed descriptor in the JSON

Now that the seed is described in the JSON, we can start using it
rather than calling out to virsh again.

Change-Id: I104557f7e20eaa842e6e60e9932a3b6cb218d6f7

commit_message:
Add 'NoRootDiskDefined' exception

This exception is used for the case when there is no root disk defined.
It was introduced in Nova with the following patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/83013/

Change-Id: I93d91a59f7261e397080e7776b199689bd5ad01d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.vmware refs/changes/33/102833/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NoRootDiskDefined(VMwareDriverException): msg_fmt = _("No root disk defined.")

commit_message:
Fix info method of ListenerSetupMixin

The listener of ListenerSetupMixin had an incorrect info implementation
that couldn't be called properly. This patch fixes the method signature.

Change-Id: I33153f04ce23474cfaffaa1db20b8582befa324d

commit_message:
Fix enable on boot when working with systemd and symlinked units

mysql on Fedora20 is actually mariadb and /usr/lib/systemd/system/mysqld.service
is a symbolic link to /usr/lib/systemd/system/mariadb.service. systemctl "enable"
doesn't work on symlinked inits like described in:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1014311

So in order to enable mysqld service properly in this case we need to
replace a service name with the real path to service file.

Closes-Bug: #1330937
Change-Id: Id823b3e377c4d0d5f1e5452fad9826232bc1f904
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/04/100504/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_path = "/lib/systemd/system/%s.service" % service if os.path.isfile(service_path): # currently "systemctl enable" doesn't work for symlinked units as described # in https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1014311, therefore replacing a symlink with its real # path if os.path.islink(service_path): real_path = os.path.realpath(service_path) result['cmd_enable'] = "sudo systemctl enable %s" % real_path result['cmd_disable'] = "sudo systemctl disable %s" % real_path else: result['cmd_enable'] = "sudo systemctl enable %s" % service result['cmd_disable'] = "sudo systemctl disable %s" % service
deleted_lines: if os.path.isfile("/lib/systemd/system/%s.service" % service): result['cmd_enable'] = "sudo systemctl enable %s" % service result['cmd_disable'] = "sudo systemctl disable %s" % service

commit_message:
Use common element select-boot-kernel-initrd

Several elements were using almost similar code to
get the current kernel and initrd inside an image.
After factoring out this code into a common element,
modify the elements to make use of it.

Change-Id: Ib547cd96b2b354b1c97342cacf5f0d0a3f70a3da

commit_message:
Adding Image Context Class

This Context Class implements Image Context Subclass
to Benchmarking Mechanism. This also adds a simple list_image benchmark
scenario which tests glance image-list command

bp benchmark-context-image

Change-Id: I272a36cebb568e8d599ebd65beb53b6a2c628b6e

added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import random import string from rally.benchmark.context import base from rally.openstack.common import log as logging from rally import osclients from rally import utils as rutils LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ImageGenerator(base.Context): __ctx_name__ = "images" __ctx_order__ = 411 __ctx_hidden__ = False RESOURCE_NAME_PREFIX = "rally_image_" CONFIG_SCHEMA = { "type": "object", "$schema": rutils.JSON_SCHEMA, "properties": { "image_url": { "type": "string", }, "image_type": { "type": "string", }, "image_container": { "type": "string", }, "amount_per_user": { "type": "integer", "minimum": 1 }, }, "additionalProperties": False } @classmethod def _generate_random_name(self, prefix=None, length=None): rand_part = ''.join(random.choice(string.lowercase) for i in range(length)) return (prefix or self.RESOURCE_NAME_PREFIX) + rand_part # pass @classmethod def _create_image(self, endpoint, image_name, container_format, image_location, disk_format, **kwargs): glance = self._get_glance_client(endpoint) args = { "name": image_name, "container_format": container_format, "disk_format": disk_format, } args.update(kwargs) if os.path.isfile(image_location): args["data"] = open(image_location) else: args["copy_from"] = image_location image = glance.create(**args) if "data" in args: args["data"].close() return image.id # pass @classmethod def _delete_image(self, endpoint, uuid): glance = self._get_glance_client(endpoint) image = glance.images.get(uuid) image.delete() # pass @classmethod def _get_glance_client(self, endpoint): return osclients.Clients(endpoint).glance() # pass def __init__(self, context): super(ImageGenerator, self).__init__(context) self.config.setdefault("amount_per_user", 1) self.config.setdefault("image_type", "qcow2") self.config.setdefault("image_container", "bare") self.endpoint = self.context["admin"]["endpoint"] # pass @rutils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Enter context: `Images`")) def setup(self): image_url = self.config["image_url"] image_type = self.config["image_type"] image_container = self.config["image_container"] image_per_user = self.config["amount_per_user"] for user in self.context["user"]: user["image_id"] = [] for i in range(image_per_user): image_id = self._create_image(user["endpoint"], self._generate_random_name(16), image_container, image_url, image_type) user["image_id"].append(image_id) # pass @rutils.log_task_wrapper(LOG.info, _("Exit context: `Images`")) def cleanup(self): for user in self.context["user"]: for image_id in user["image_id"]: self._delete_image(user["endpoint"], image_id) # pass

commit_message:
NSX: revert queue extension name change

The following patch: d7aa2dfcb14b84e2ef3242fb0787200d852d6103 renamed the
nvp-qos extension to qos-queue which breaks the integration with nova as
nova checks for the nvp-qos extension to be loaded and now it's called
qos-queue. This patch adds back nvp-qos for trunk chasers and another
patch will migrate nova from nvp-qos to qos-queue.

Change-Id: I563aed6b6c4551489989f846a619d54020d0b5ee
closes-bug: 1329071

commit_message:
Build retry loop for screen sessions

There is a timing window where we might lose the commands being
stuffed into screen because bash is spawning. In those cases, loop
around and try building screen sessions again.

Change-Id: I49247de06bbd59424cb10fb9a8db145907be5138
Related-Bug: #1331274
(cherry picked from commit 0afa912e99dc9bad8b490960beb8f0cf85750dcc)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/68/102968/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function _start_in_screen { local service=$1 local cmd=$2 local screen_name=${SCREEN_NAME:-stack} local status_dir=${SERVICE_DIR:-${DEST}/status} local service_dir="$status_dir/$screen_name" local pid="$service_dir/$service.pid" local failure="$service_dir/$service.failure" if [[ -n ${SCREEN_LOGDIR} ]]; then local logfile=${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${service}.${CURRENT_LOG_TIME}.log local shortlog=${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${service}.log # this whole dance is done because of slow nodes screen -S $screen_name -p $service -X logfile ${logfile} screen -S $screen_name -p $service -X log on ln -sf ${logfile} ${shortlog} fi NL=`echo -ne '\015'` # This fun command does the following: # - the passed server command is backgrounded # - the pid of the background process is saved in the usual place # - the server process is brought back to the foreground # - if the server process exits prematurely the fg command errors # and a message is written to stdout and the service failure file # The pid saved can be used in screen_stop() as a process group # id to kill off all child processes echo "Running: $cmd & echo \$! >$pid; fg || echo \"$service failed to start\" | tee \"$failure\"$NL" screen -S $screen_name -p $service -X stuff "$cmd & echo \$! >$pid; fg || echo \"$service failed to start\" | tee \"$failure\"$NL" } function _is_running_in_screen { local service=$1 local screen_name=${SCREEN_NAME:-stack} local status_dir=${SERVICE_DIR:-${DEST}/status} local service_dir="$status_dir/$screen_name" local pid="$service_dir/$service.pid" local failure="$service_dir/$service.failure" if [[ ! -e "$pid" && ! -e "$failure" ]]; then # if we don't have a pid or a failure for why, the command may not # have stuffed in there echo "Warning: neither $pid nor $failure exist, $service didn't seem to start" return 1 fi if [[ -n ${SCREEN_LOGDIR} ]]; then # if we should be logging, but we don't have a log file, something is wrong local logfile=${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${service}.${CURRENT_LOG_TIME}.log if [[ ! -e "$logfile" ]]; then echo "Warning: expected logfile $logfile not found, something wrong with starting $service" return 1 fi fi return 0 } local service=$1 local cmd=$2 local screen_name=${SCREEN_NAME:-stack} local status_dir=${SERVICE_DIR:-${DEST}/status} local service_dir="$status_dir/$screen_name" local use_screen=$(trueorfalse True $USE_SCREEN) local pid="$service_dir/$service.pid" screen_rc "$service" "$cmd" if [[ "$use_screen" = "True" ]]; then screen -S $screen_name -X screen -t $service # this retry loop brought to you by slow compute nodes, screen raciness, # and frustration in upgrading. local screen_tries=0 while [ "$screen_tries" -lt 10 ]; do _start_in_screen "$service" "$cmd" if _is_running_in_screen $service; then screen_tries=10 else screen_tries=$[screen_tries + 1] echo "Failed to start service after $screen_tries attempt(s), retrying" if [[ "$screen_tries" -eq 10 ]]; then echo "Too many retries, giving up" exit 1 fi sleep 1 fi done run_process "$service" "$cmd" >$pid
deleted_lines: SCREEN_NAME=${SCREEN_NAME:-stack} SERVICE_DIR=${SERVICE_DIR:-${DEST}/status} USE_SCREEN=$(trueorfalse True $USE_SCREEN) screen_rc "$1" "$2" if [[ "$USE_SCREEN" = "True" ]]; then screen -S $SCREEN_NAME -X screen -t $1 if [[ -n ${SCREEN_LOGDIR} ]]; then screen -S $SCREEN_NAME -p $1 -X logfile ${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${1}.${CURRENT_LOG_TIME}.log screen -S $SCREEN_NAME -p $1 -X log on ln -sf ${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${1}.${CURRENT_LOG_TIME}.log ${SCREEN_LOGDIR}/screen-${1}.log fi # sleep to allow bash to be ready to be send the command - we are # creating a new window in screen and then sends characters, so if # bash isn't running by the time we send the command, nothing happens sleep 3 NL=`echo -ne '\015'` # This fun command does the following: # - the passed server command is backgrounded # - the pid of the background process is saved in the usual place # - the server process is brought back to the foreground # - if the server process exits prematurely the fg command errors # and a message is written to stdout and the service failure file # The pid saved can be used in screen_stop() as a process group # id to kill off all child processes screen -S $SCREEN_NAME -p $1 -X stuff "$2 & echo \$! >$SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$1.pid; fg || echo \"$1 failed to start\" | tee \"$SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$1.failure\"$NL" run_process "$1" "$2" >$SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$1.pid

commit_message:
Update python-neutronclient>=2.3.5,<3

Nova has a few bug fixes in progress that are using the OverQuotaClient
exception class defined in python-neutronclient-2.3.5 so bump the
minimum version.

Related-Bug: #1331353
Related-Bug: #1210598
Related-Bug: #1301117

Change-Id: I0a8de70d8362380adc330ecbb41275755362bd52

commit_message:
Semantic version support for pbr

OpenStack uses semver but pbr doesn't actually understand it today.
Teaching it to understand semver will allow less thought and more
automation by developers, as well as better and clearer version
numbers for folk doing continual deployment of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Ifeb73fdd6a8acf3bf313f28a5079830c2b075b7a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/08/96608/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. ============================= Teaching PBR about semver ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/pbr-semver OpenStack uses semver but pbr doesn't actually understand it today. Teaching it to understand semver will allow less thought and more automation by developers, as well as better and clearer version numbers for folk doing continual deployment of OpenStack. Problem description =================== With postversioning (the default) given a tag of 1.3.2 pbr generates per-commit versions of 1.3.2.N.g$sha. pip currently considers such versions invalid, but if pip learns about build tags - the g$sha, then the version would be considered a release, but often the intent of an untagged commit is to be a developer version for local installs / testing. So this is not PEP-440 compliant. Conflicting with this is the desire of CD deployers and CD packagers to have monotonic versions that can be used to install packages on e.g. Debian systems, but subsequent tags can collide with these versions as well. PEP-440 versions do not map entirely well to version_info - a core python concept but some users of pbr export version_info tuples in their module, and offering that would enable them to use pbr. Lastly, semver provides deterministic rules for picking the next version number which at the moment is a developer task. Developers can easily get this wrong because they're having to think 'what version next' vs categorising the changes in the version. In summary: * The versions pbr generates are not always pip compatible (PEP440). * The versions pbr generates for non-tagged commits are marked as releases rather than dev versions. This means that if pushed into a mirror pip will default to installing them rather than the latest release. * There is no tooling support to reconcile the needs of devs (give me a version to install) and CD'ers (give me a unique version # for this commit in trunk that sorts correctly with all other trunk versions). * There is no tooling support for picking new (postversioned) version numbers. Proposed change =============== * Change from emitting 1.2.3a4 (which some projects are using) to 1.2.3.0a4, updating the semver docs accordingly. This gets us PEP440 compatibility. * Add metadata fields to setup.cfg to allow recording the last release that had been made when a backwards incompatible change was made, or when a deprecation is made, or major new functionality. This allows us to calculate the next semver version number automatically (and patches in gerrit can update this as development progresses). * For untagged postversioned builds, generate devN versions - e.g. x.y.z.dev4.gHASH, where x.y.z are derived by applying the semver rules with the metadata about the most recent change of each type. * Provide a new command to do the git tagging for developers. It will accept parameters allowing manual control, but will enforce semver is being followed (e.g. if there is a newer tag than the version being tagged in the history of the branch, thats an error). Alpha, beta and rc tagging can be automated too. * Provide a python API for getting version_info style version data. * Provider a new command to output Debian package version compatible version strings. This primarily involves translating PEP-440 precedence rules into Debian ~ and . component separators. * sdist and the new debian version string command will accept a --no-rc parameter which will tell them to only ever emit versions that are a) normal releases or b) devN builds. This resolves the sorting ambiguity in semver where devN is lower than *any* pre-release build, but version numbers may not have both a pre-release version *and* a devN version component. CD deployers can then include --no-rc in their scripts and have a consistent timeline (as long as they're pulling from a monotonically advancing branch) while regular users and packagers will want to select regular builds only. There is one caveat here which is that new point releases of old versions must not be merged into the history of trunk, or the devN versions will be reset at that point. New version rules ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ There are four incrementable components in a version: major, minor, patch and pre-release. The following is a description of how pbr will implement the assignment rules described by semver.rst. 1. If there are one or more tags for a commit then the highest such tag is considered to be the 'last tag' for these rules. 1. If the last tag is a pre-release tag, then the --no-rc option is consulted. If set, pre-release tags are not considered when looking for for the last tag. 1. The highest eligible tag reachable from the commit is considered to be the 'last tag'. If there is more than one tag with equal distance (e.g. an rc and a final tag on a single commit) then the highest tag is still used. If there is no tag reachable at all, ``0.0.0`` is implied as the last tag. Tags are eligible if they are PEP-440 version strings, reachable from the commit in the git history, and not excluded by the --no-rc option. 1. If the distance to the last tag is non-zero at minimum a patch level increment is required and the version shall be a devN version. 1. If the option ``pbr_deprecation`` is set in setup.cfg to the same major and minor components (e.g. last tag is 1.2.3 and pbr_deprecation is 1.2.1, or just 1.2) then a minor increment is required. 1. If the option ``pbr_major_feature`` is set in setup.cfg to the same major and minor components (e.g. last tag is 1.2.3 and pbr_major_feature is 1.2.1 or just 1.2) then a minor increment is required. 1. If the option ``pbr_backwards_incompatible`` is set in setup.cfg to the same major component (e.g. last tag is 1.2.3 and pbr_backwards_incompatible is 1.2.1 or 1.2 or just 1) then a major increment is required. 1. If the last tag has a major component of 0 then major and minor increments are right-shifted. That is a major increment becomes a minor increment and a minor increment becomes a patch level increment. Using these rules a few examples may aid in clarity:: no tags, one commit last_tag = 0.0.0 tag_distance = 1 version = 0.0.1.dev1.gHASH tag of 0.0.1 on a commit last_tag = 0.0.1 tag_distance = 0 version = 0.0.1 tag of 0.0.1.0a4 on a commit, 5 commits since the start no_rc = True last_tag = 0.0.0 tag_distance = 5 # distance to origin version = 0.0.1.dev5.gHASH tag of 0.12.2 on this commit pbr_deprecation = 0.11 version = 0.12.2 tag of 0.12.2 2 commits ago pbr_deprecation = 0.11 version = 0.12.3.dev2.gHASH tag of 0.12.2 2 commits ago pbr_deprecation = 0.12 version = 0.13.0.dev2.gHASH Alternatives ------------ We could do nothing, but right now folk are reinventing stuff in adhoc fashions and there is no ability to reuse their solutions in a systematic fashion. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- No public APIs change (since pbr has approximately no public APIs at all). New public APIs will be added that we have to support. Security impact --------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The needed calculations are trivial, so non-trivially slower. Configuration Impact -------------------- There are three new options described above. They will default to None and have no impact unless set. Once set they can be left alone for as long as desired. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers can largely ignore this - it will just result in PEP-440 compatible versions. If desired they can take advantage of the new features - export version_info tuples in their projects, record when they make breaking changes and have pbr enforce appropriate version changes for them. These options are all opt-in with one exception: the change of generated numbers to be PEP-440 compatible, and to automatically increment to a devN version of the next release rather than doing an incremented release build. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Robert Collins (lifeless) Other contributors: Anyone I can rope in. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-1 Work Items ---------- * Cleanup internal logic in PBR to separate out the setuptools interactions and the version modelling. * Add new configuration options. * Add auto-incrementing feature. * Add tagging feature. * Add debian-version feature. * Add version_info feature. Incubation ========== None Adoption -------- ALL OF THEM. Library ------- pbr Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None. It shall be perfect. Documentation Impact ==================== The pbr manual (in the pbr tree) needs fleshing out to cover this behaviour. Dependencies ============ None References ========== * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/pbr-postversion-semver * https://www.mail-archive.com/openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org/msg19450.html .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Misuse of i18n log translation to output error message

I found a misuse of i18n log translation for error message
in "cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py'.

The "%s' can not be translated. In this case, the "message'
must be i18ning and then the "message" should be output
using LOG.error().

Change-Id: I4495522d337764dc28186225f4594a227ac3e555
Signed-off-by: Mitsuhiro Tanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com>
Closes-Bug: 1334334
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/15/102615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: message = (_("Destination Volume Group %s does not exist") % dest_vg) LOG.error(message)
deleted_lines: message = ("Destination Volume Group %s does not exist" % dest_vg) LOG.error(_('%s'), message)

commit_message:
Add URI validation method

There is the library 'rfc3987' which can validate URI data format, but
the library cannot be used for OpenStack due to the license.
This patch adds URI validation method based on rfc3986 and the method
will be used in jsonschema validation in some OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I36b5c7c03348359eb7b99c331d24a5e439f2d149
Related-Bug: #1326599

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslotest import base as test_base from openstack.common import uriutils class UriUtilsTest(test_base.BaseTestCase): def test_is_uri_like_with_host_only(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost')) self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('ftp://localhost')) self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://192.168.0.100')) self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://2001:db8::9abc')) def test_is_uri_like_with_port(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost:8080')) def test_is_uri_like_with_userinfo(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://foo@localhost')) def test_is_uri_like_with_path(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost/')) self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost/foo')) self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost/foo/bar')) def test_is_uri_like_with_query(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost?foo=bar')) def test_is_uri_like_with_fragment(self): self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://localhost#nose')) def test_is_uri_like_with_all(self): uri = 'http://user@localhost:8080/foo/bar?foo=bar#nose' self.assertTrue(uriutils.is_uri_like(uri)) def test_is_uri_like_with_invalid_scheme(self): self.assertFalse(uriutils.is_uri_like('http:localhost')) self.assertFalse(uriutils.is_uri_like('0ttp://localhost')) def test_is_uri_like_with_invalid_host(self): self.assertFalse(uriutils.is_uri_like('http://local\host'))

commit_message:
Switch over to mox3

mox3 is a Python 3.x compatible drop-in and allows
to continue with the porting effort to Python 3.x with
minimal code changes.

Closes-Bug: #1283482
Change-Id: Ib052f1b87e312481e4c7c8d775ece94f53e7106b

deleted_lines: Dir.chdir(File.dirname(__FILE__)) { (s = lambda { |f| File.exist?(f) ? require(f) : Dir.chdir("..") { s.call(f) } }).call("spec/spec_helper.rb") } describe Puppet::Type.type(:physical_volume) do before do @type = Puppet::Type.type(:physical_volume) stub_default_provider! end it "should exist" do Puppet::Type.type(:physical_volume).should_not be_nil end describe "the name parameter" do it "should exist" do @type.attrclass(:name).should_not be_nil end it "should only allow fully qualified files" do lambda { @type.new :name => "mypv" }.should raise_error(Puppet::Error) end it "should support fully qualified names" do @type.new(:name => "/my/pv")[:name].should == "/my/pv" end end describe "the 'ensure' parameter" do it "should exist" do @type.attrclass(:ensure).should_not be_nil end it "should support 'present' as a value" do with(:name => "/my/pv", :ensure => :present) do |resource| resource[:ensure].should == :present end end it "should support 'absent' as a value" do with(:name => "/my/pv", :ensure => :absent) do |resource| resource[:ensure].should == :absent end end it "should not support other values" do specifying(:name => "/my/pv", :ensure => :foobar).should raise_error(Puppet::Error) end end end

commit_message:
Adapt synced puppetlab-cinder for Fuel usage

Implements: blueprint merge-openstack-puppet-modules

Key moments:
  - Avoid changing upstream "cinder" module and  move all our
    custom settings into openstack::cinder class.

Change-Id: Ia972a2ab6bacba16c4a7d503786651f85a700fd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/71/101471/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: } case $queue_provider { 'rabbitmq': { if $rabbit_ha_queues { if !is_array($amqp_hosts) { $rabbit_hosts_real = split($amqp_hosts, ',') } else { $rabbit_hosts_real = $amqp_hosts } # ::cinder module accepts rabbit_host and rabbit_port and then # makes "rabbit_host:rabbit_port" from it. So we need to split # our aqmp_hosts or provide defaults $rabbit_host_array[0] = '127.0.0.1' $rabbit_host_array[1] = '5672' } else { $rabbit_hosts_real = false # ::cinder module accepts rabbit_host and rabbit_port and then # makes "rabbit_host:rabbit_port" from it. So we need to split # our aqmp_hosts or provide defaults $rabbit_host_array = split($amqp_hosts, ':') } class { '::cinder': package_ensure => $::openstack_version['cinder'], rpc_backend => 'cinder.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu', rabbit_host => $rabbit_host_array[0], rabbit_port => $rabbit_host_array[1], rabbit_hosts => $rabbit_hosts_real, rabbit_userid => $amqp_user, rabbit_password => $amqp_password, rabbit_virtual_host => $rabbit_virtual_host, database_connection => $sql_connection, verbose => $verbose, use_syslog => $use_syslog, log_facility => $syslog_log_facility, debug => $debug, database_idle_timeout => $idle_timeout, } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/kombu_reconnect_delay': value => '5.0'; } } 'qpid': { $rpc_backend = 'cinder.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid' cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/qpid_hosts': value => $amqp_hosts; 'DEFAULT/qpid_username': value => $amqp_user; 'DEFAULT/qpid_password': value => $amqp_password; } } } keystone_enabled => true, ratelimits => $cinder_rate_limits if ($physical_volume) { class { 'lvm': vg => $volume_group, pv => $physical_volume, before => Service['cinder-volume'], } } class {'cinder::volume::rbd': rbd_pool => $::ceph::cinder_pool, rbd_user => $::ceph::cinder_user, rbd_secret_uuid => $::ceph::rbd_secret_uuid, } } } } if $use_syslog { cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/use_syslog_rfc_format': value => true; } } cinder_config { 'database/max_pool_size': value => $max_pool_size; 'database/max_retries': value => $max_retries; 'database/max_overflow': value => $max_overflow; } }
deleted_lines: cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/auth_strategy': value => 'keystone' } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/rabbit_ha_queues': value => 'True' } } class { 'cinder::base': package_ensure => $::openstack_version['cinder'], queue_provider => $queue_provider, amqp_hosts => $amqp_hosts, amqp_user => $amqp_user, amqp_password => $amqp_password, sql_connection => $sql_connection, verbose => $verbose, use_syslog => $use_syslog, syslog_log_facility => $syslog_log_facility, debug => $debug, max_retries => $max_retries, max_pool_size => $max_pool_size, max_overflow => $max_overflow, idle_timeout => $idle_timeout, } cinder_rate_limits => $cinder_rate_limits physical_volume => $physical_volume, class {'cinder::volume::ceph': } } } } }

commit_message:
Automatically expire worker information

To ensure that we do not try to retain all worker
information in memory for all of time we should use
the underlying expiry mechanism to expire worker data
according to some expiry time limit.

Unless overridden the default expiry for worker info
is infinite to not affect existing WBE usage, but it
can be provided to reduce the amount of time the worker
information is stored as needed.

Fixes bug 1334875

Change-Id: Id02f00aed473cb0b941e290abf9cbe1c88b0d5cd

commit_message:
Perform cleanup before starting net_probe.py

If net_probe.py fails for unknown reason,
daemon process will hang there forever and next
net_probe.py run will fail with socket.bind error

Change-Id: I1f5889d59dc60aa374fdf3f9dd8e3e5e7c0a115b
Closes-Bug: #1259935
(cherry picked from commit d4edf32197c59495fd48662ede67f3751ee15d9b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/13/103013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cleanup_netprobe def cleanup_netprobe status = run("pkill net_probe.py && sleep 2 && pgrep net_probe.py") reply.fail! "Cant stop net_probe.py execution." unless status == 1 end

Perform cleanup before starting net_probe.py

subject: Fix lazy translation UnicodeErrors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-26 19:08:10.000000000', 'files': ['glance/api/v1/upload_utils.py', 'glance/tests/unit/test_quota.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/834e1f2150c6f2afd92036e6b7f53afee4006682', 'message': "Fix lazy translation UnicodeErrors

upload_utils is concatenating str and Message objects which doesn't work
on python 2, so change the str to a unicode object.

test_quota.py was casting Message objects to str which fails for the
same reason, so rather than cast to str, cast using six.text_type.

See oslo commit 2cfc1a78d8063cf20083cf7df796d730a576551c for history and
details on why the Message object doesn't support __str__ casting.

This is a small part of a larger effort that the oslo team will be
rolling out with graduation and adoption of the oslo-i18n library.

Closes-Bug: #1334774

Change-Id: I9d3f29c661f1afffabbbbb499f48d37ef5a8fcee
"}]
commit_message:
Fix lazy translation UnicodeErrors

upload_utils is concatenating str and Message objects which doesn't work
on python 2, so change the str to a unicode object.

test_quota.py was casting Message objects to str which fails for the
same reason, so rather than cast to str, cast using six.text_type.

See oslo commit 2cfc1a78d8063cf20083cf7df796d730a576551c for history and
details on why the Message object doesn't support __str__ casting.

This is a small part of a larger effort that the oslo team will be
rolling out with graduation and adoption of the oslo-i18n library.

Closes-Bug: #1334774

Change-Id: I9d3f29c661f1afffabbbbb499f48d37ef5a8fcee

deleted_lines: self.assertIn("Attempted: 2, Maximum: 1", str(exc)) self.assertIn("Attempted: 2, Maximum: 1", str(exc)) self.assertIn('Attempted: 2, Maximum: 0', str(exc)) self.assertIn('Attempted: 2, Maximum: 1', str(exc)) self.assertIn('Attempted: 1, Maximum: 0', str(exc)) self.assertIn('Attempted: 3, Maximum: 1', str(exc)) self.assertIn('Attempted: 2, Maximum: 1', str(exc))

commit_message:
Make Juno-Trunk relationship clearer

Recently we've had some people trying to install Icehouse with
the Trunk guide. This no longer works.

In this patch, changes are made which will deliberately break the guide
by changing the package repositories to Juno versions that do not exist
yet.

The hope is that this will encourage people to seek out the most appropriate
guide for them - likely icehouse.

Change-Id: I42393f466c910e1d2cb350134efa815184c66902

commit_message:
debug level logs should not be translated

According to the OpenStack translation policy available at
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards debug messages
should not be translated. Like mentioned in several changes in
Nova by garyk this is to help prioritize log translation.

Change-Id: I639624cbe64749085654b32ac85596fdae577230

commit_message:
Disable rescheduling instance when no retry info

When scheduler_max_attempts=1 means disable rescheduling, compute
won't reschedule instance before. But build_and_run_instance didn't
hornor this behavior. And cause nova reschedule instance infinitely.
This patch fix this problem, make build_and_run_instance won't reschedule
instance without retry info.

Change-Id: I52d6569c1731b5fd5a10f39ff04a40b43d3857a1
Partial-Bug: #1326207
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/97728/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: retry = filter_properties.get('retry', None) if not retry: # no retry information, do not reschedule. LOG.debug("Retry info not present, will not reschedule") self._cleanup_allocated_networks(context, instance, requested_networks) self._set_instance_error_state(context, instance.uuid) return

commit_message:
NSX sync cache: add a flag to skip item deletion

This new flag will prevent updates on single resources, which
can happen asynchronously to the main synchronization thread,
from processing the 'changed' flag for items in the cache and
delete items not present anymore in NSX.

This will avoid failures seen in CI runs where the sync
thread failed because of a KeyError because some items where
concurrently removed from the NSX cache.

Change-Id: I6a11b8dabb1e9481dc807b5fbba17c9027dad5f2
Closes-Bug: #1329650
(cherry picked from commit bd4ef02dc12122ad019ada803fd1a2bb2c56a5a2)

commit_message:
Check neutron agent extension support in Info page

Some neutron plugin don't support agent extension, and
Horizon show 404 error on admin info page.
In this commit, we are going to add check if agent
extension supported or not.
Closes-bug: 1331032

Change-Id: I5cd3ec747c650fc2b826d55f39be618eca1b7caa

commit_message:
Properly invalidate cache for get_*_by_name methods

Use the original name for invalidating the cache on the
get_project_by_name and get_domain_by_name when performing update
operations on the name attributes.

Change-Id: If58a3b0a47501096f9fa9eb9cd7a6057f7b29298
Closes-Bug: #1311142
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/82/101082/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_domain_rename_invalidates_get_domain_by_name_cache(self): domain = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'enabled': True} domain_id = domain['id'] domain_name = domain['name'] self.assignment_api.create_domain(domain_id, domain) domain_ref = self.assignment_api.get_domain(domain_id) domain_ref['name'] = uuid.uuid4().hex self.assignment_api.update_domain(domain_id, domain_ref) self.assertRaises(exception.DomainNotFound, self.assignment_api.get_domain_by_name, domain_name) @tests.skip_if_cache_disabled('assignment') def test_project_rename_invalidates_get_project_by_name_cache(self): domain = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'enabled': True} project = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'domain_id': domain['id']} project_id = project['id'] project_name = project['name'] self.assignment_api.create_domain(domain['id'], domain) # Create a project self.assignment_api.create_project(project_id, project) self.assignment_api.get_project(project_id) project['name'] = uuid.uuid4().hex self.assignment_api.update_project(project_id, project) self.assertRaises(exception.ProjectNotFound, self.assignment_api.get_project_by_name, project_name, domain['id']) @tests.skip_if_cache_disabled('assignment')

subject: Exit rpc_loop when SIGTERM is recieved in ovs-agent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-25 13:10:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1370d200a88e12f03b13d03fe8c065d3c5bad1b5', 'message': 'Exit rpc_loop when SIGTERM is recieved in ovs-agent

Previously ovs-agent exitted with exit code 1 after SIGTERM was sent.
SIGTERM should shutdown agent gracefully and exit code should be 0.

This patch introduces module level variable to drive main rpc loop.
Since ovs agent runs in one process there is no need to tie variable
with process.

Closes-Bug: #1334264

Previously ovs-agent exitted with exit code 1 after SIGTERM was sent.
SIGTERM should shutdown agent gracefully and exit code should be 0.

This patch introduces module level variable to drive main rpc loop.
Since ovs agent runs in one process there is no need to tie variable
with process.

commit_message:
Exit rpc_loop when SIGTERM is recieved in ovs-agent

Previously ovs-agent exited with exit code 1 after SIGTERM was received.
SIGTERM should shutdown agent gracefully and exit code should be 0.

Closes-Bug: #1334264
Change-Id: I23e81cee5ae9e9fdabbe1377420b0902f47be8a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/19/102519/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.openstack.common import lockutils_got_sigterm = False while not _got_sigterm:@lockutils.synchronized('ovs-sigterm') def handle_sigterm(signum, frame): global _got_sigterm _got_sigterm = True
deleted_lines: while True:def handle_sigterm(signum, frame): sys.exit(1) sys.exit(0)

commit_message:
Add Extensions to the v2 API

*Provide a framework for adding extensions to the v2 API.
*Port the Quotas extension
*Add v2 extension unit tests
*Fix small bug with noauth middleware and quota retrieval

blueprint v2-extensions
Closes-Bug: #1333892
Change-Id: I1dc395e7266a17c8c860e00ee470e14e94e82769

commit_message:
Fix unicode display in parameters

When parameters contain unicode, stack-show will display unicode
as '\u2665'. It's not easy to read by human.
This change will change '\u2665' to readable unicode char '' when
display to users.

Change-Id: I00a74943138b292b71f848966ee64a658be64bc2
Partial-Bug: #1330370

commit_message:
Un-nest some sections of code

Reversing the logic in a few of the booleans and returning earlier
allows us to not have to be nested quite so deep.

Change-Id: Ia0dad183563381e9eb8c790ba61d0b350d74421d

subject: Fix 'fake' driver unable to finish a deploy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-26 22:25:28.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/drivers/modules/fake.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/dbd96f3f2c1e95d7bfdd33fe155e43a383383a93', 'message': "Fix 'fake' driver unable to finish a deploy

The 'fake' driver is not returning any status from driver.deploy or
driver.tear_down, which prevents the completion of a provision state
transition with this driver.

Change-Id: I844dc03f35da23eb81235abdc16a79afc9835235
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'fake' driver unable to finish a deploy

The 'fake' driver is not returning any status from driver.deploy or
driver.tear_down, which prevents the completion of a provision state
transition with this driver.

Change-Id: I844dc03f35da23eb81235abdc16a79afc9835235
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/62/102962/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return states.DEPLOYDONE return states.DELETED
deleted_lines: pass pass

commit_message:
Improve --debug logging output

This change makes the following improvements to the output of a heat
command with the --debug option set:
* Silences spurious logging from iso8601 and urllib3.connectionpool
* Removes the line number from the logging format, since the intent
  of --debug is to show the user what network requests are occuring.

Change-Id: Iccbae01a1a5b85db0770a4f56c3b48788dc3008a
Closes-bug: #1324470

deleted_lines: format="%(levelname)s (%(module)s:%(lineno)d) %(message)s",

subject: Fix update agent return agent_id with string for os-agents v3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-24 02:55:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6e277f2e0e864fad2468da213ea8ba5045234570', 'message': 'Fix update agent return agent_id with string for os-agents v3

Currently the agent update return agent_id with integer, that is
inconsistent with the response of agent create and index. It because
agent update use the agent_id that passed from url as the response.
This problem is fixed by adding integer validation and conversion for
the input id.

And the API sample tests provide agent_id with string type in the fake
data. This patch fix this problem for API sample files and tests.

And for back-compatibility, we should add translator for v2.1 API later.
Then this fix will be exposed after v3 API feature exposed by microversion
in the future.

Change-Id: Ia9c1034a325b77a2057934cc80b6eab679ff1d2b
Partial-Bug: #1333494

commit_message:
Fix update agent return agent_id with string for os-agents v3

Currently the agent update return agent_id with integer, that is
inconsistent with the response of agent create and index. It because
agent update use the agent_id that passed from url as the response.
This problem is fixed by converting the agent id as integer.

And the API sample tests provide agent_id with string type in the fake
data. This patch fix this problem for API sample files and tests.

And for back-compatibility, we should add translator for v2.1 API later.
Then this fix will be exposed after v3 API feature exposed by microversion
in the future.

DocImpact: The agent_is is changed to integer type for agents'update action.

Change-Id: Ia9c1034a325b77a2057934cc80b6eab679ff1d2b
Partial-Bug: #1333494
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/102092/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "agent_id": 1,
deleted_lines: "agent_id": "1",

commit_message:
Fix live migration for File/Volume based Instances

- Open libvirt ports for migration http://wiki.libvirt.org/page/FAQ
- Add python-novaclient for compute nodes to provide nova CLI
- Change libvirt_disk_cachemodes to"file=directsync","block=none".

This allows live block migration, as DirectSync mode is like writethrough, but it bypasses the host page cache.

Closes-Bug: 1329953
Change-Id: Ie7cee823fac70f9c2dd46c04f8651cec6bddccc4

commit_message:
Exclude docker from the admin net masquerading

We should exclude -s docker0 form the nailgun iptables
rule for admin network masquerading in order to
elliminate the potential issues related with race condition
during master node deployment.

Closes-bug: #1332517

Change-Id: I942da109d83cce65880a3f27cb1d5301d300da50
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/12/101912/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $rule = "-s $network ! -o docker0 -j MASQUERADE"
deleted_lines: $rule = "-s $network -j MASQUERADE"

subject: Avoid reading real config files in unit test
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-14 11:32:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/f475f433aad7e46adbb0c8b1aac3957ab53f41fb', 'message': 'Avoid reading real config files in unit test

When we call oslo.config.cfg.CONF(), it will do basic setup and
search configuration files under certain directories, by default,
they are [/etc, /etc/ceilometer, ~/, ~/.ceilometer]. However, we
should avoid such behaviour when we run unit test code, because that
if the system has run devstack or installed ceilometer services,
then /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf will exist, then unit test result
can be different.

So we should mock the default searching directories of cfg in the
begining of all unit tests, which will call cfg.CONF() at somewhere
during the test. The best place to mock the default directories
can be ceilometer.test.base.BaseTestCase, which should be used as
parent class of all other test classes.

Note: since this patch sets default searching directory to
{repo}/etc/ceilometer, you can run the unit test with different settings
which are set in etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf (not tracked by git).

Note: ceilometer.tests.objectstore.test_swift_middleware.TestSwiftMiddleware
(actually all) should inherit from base.BaseTestCase, since its test_rpc_setup
will call cfg.CONF() in ceilometer.service.prepare_service.

Note: mock.patch.stopall has compatibility problem with oslo.fixture,
so this patch slightly refactors the
tests.compute.pollsters.base.TestPollsterBase.setUp method.

Change-Id: I533ffb2ba2c9be0223cecbcf04176312e4a96369
Closes-Bug: #1328550

commit_message:
Avoid reading real config files in unit test

When we call oslo.config.cfg.CONF(), it will do basic setup and
search configuration files under certain directories, by default,
they are [/etc, /etc/ceilometer, ~/, ~/.ceilometer]. However, we
should avoid such behaviour when we run unit test code, because that
if the system has run devstack or installed ceilometer services,
then /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf will exist, then unit test result
can be different.

So we should mock the default searching directories of cfg in the
begining of all unit tests, which will call cfg.CONF() at somewhere
during the test. The best place to mock the default directories
can be ceilometer.test.base.BaseTestCase, which should be used as
parent class of all other test classes.

Note: since this patch sets default searching directory to
{repo}/etc/ceilometer, you can run the unit test with different settings
which are set in etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf (not tracked by git).

Note: mock.patch.stopall has compatibility problem with oslo.fixture,
so this patch slightly refactors the
tests.compute.pollsters.base.TestPollsterBase.setUp method.

Change-Id: I533ffb2ba2c9be0223cecbcf04176312e4a96369
Closes-Bug: #1328550

subject: Fix object code direct use of other object modules
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-18 00:34:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e9534a6828c2238b71fa41c21da67428658a72d4', 'message': "Fix object code direct use of other object modules

The object code itself should not explicitly reference its own objects,
as objects could be subclassed.

Also: There were a few objects that had their own __init__()s that
didn't support accepting 'context' or kwargs. At some point here, we
should also require that context is passed when instantiating the
objects. So, I added the (currently optional) context argument on some
object instantiations near the places I was touching.

Change-Id: Icf631c770e347b4bb32999c4ba2431d1db49e11c

commit_message:
Fix object code direct use of other object modules

The object code itself should not explicitly reference its own objects,
as objects could be subclassed.

Also: There were a few objects that had their own __init__()s that
didn't support accepting 'context' or kwargs. At some point here, we
should also require that context is passed when instantiating the
objects. So, I added the (currently optional) context argument on some
object instantiations near the places I was touching.

Partial-Blueprint: object-subclassing

Change-Id: Icf631c770e347b4bb32999c4ba2431d1db49e11c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/94058/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import objects return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(context), objects.VirtualInterface, db_vifs) return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(context), objects.VirtualInterface, db_vifs)
deleted_lines: return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), VirtualInterface, db_vifs) return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), VirtualInterface, db_vifs)

commit_message:
Fix the rest of direct uses of instance module objects

This switches the remaining occurences of
nova.objects.instance.Instance* to nova.objects.Instance*.

Partial-Blueprint: object-subclassing

Change-Id: I3017c149cc9fbc6b1fbecb003dc55455b1dcd12c

Add select-boot-kernel-initrd element

Encapsulate the new select-boot-kernel-initrd common function
into an element so other elements can make use of it.

commit_message:
Sync loggers and handlers from Horizon upstream

In order to prevent too verbose logging, use recommended
patterns from upstream examples
https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/2014.1.1/openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example

Closes-bug: #1330825

Change-Id: Ie93816388d2bb97d6543c3452398ec15e5c8fd31
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Move hints building/filtering onto object

Building and applying driver hints is on the controller however there is
nothing about that method that has anything to do with the controller.

Move this into the driver hints code.

Change-Id: I2a1fbc153e1d36796056f3cfe1a9252f4dc9739e

commit_message:
Added removable drives in user installation dialog

This patch is to avoid missing hard drives which
are present but are marked as removable.

Change-Id: If2524b3dff36703e42fb46da2bd042b3ac63f681
Closes-Bug: #1290933
(cherry picked from commit b5d7e605788857562f56d5a0d2bad78a9dbeeefe)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/39/101839/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: removable_drives="" else removable_drives="${removable_drives} ${drv}"default_drive=`echo ${drives} ${removable_drives} | awk '{print $1}'`set ${drives} ${removable_drives}if [ ${numdrives} -gt 1 ] || [ `echo ${drives} | wc -w` -eq 0 ] ; then echo "Possible choices" echo "Persistent drives: ${drives}" echo "Removable drives: ${removable_drives}" if [ `echo ${drives} | wc -w` -eq 1 ] ; then read -t 30 -p "Choose hard drive: " tgtdrive || tgtdrive=$default_drive else read -p "Choose hard drive: " tgtdrive fi for drive in ${drives[@]} ${removable_drives[@]}; do
deleted_lines: set ${drives}if [ ${numdrives} -gt 1 ]; then echo "Possible choices: ${drives}" read -p "Choose hard drive: " tgtdrive for drive in ${drives[@]}; do

subject: encoding error in file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-26 18:45:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/8408dc7ff7c9e687fb8fdce3910a26cf5b5e433d', 'message': 'Oslo: encoding error in file

There is a non-printable character (c2a0) in a comment line, which
in a new Neutron test case causes a StringException. There are
three issues here.

1) Encoding issue in the file.
2) No detection of encoding issues in files.
3) Neutron tests mask the failure detail

This addresses the first issue. Bug 1334798 in Neutron was created
for the last issue. Oslo team is aware of the second issue.

Change-Id: I8cfa6c93085a26666a8b4bee06dcd52709d04a95
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-26 18:49:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/11034ca4e1444ac5518001faa9ad2ea3fccb1546', 'message': 'encoding error in file

There is a non-printable character (c2a0) in a comment line, which
in a new Neutron test case causes a StringException. There are
three issues here.

1) Encoding issue in the file.
2) No detection of encoding issues in files.
3) Neutron tests mask the failure detail

This addresses the first issue. Bug 1334798 in Neutron was created
for the last issue. Oslo team is aware of the second issue.

Change-Id: I8cfa6c93085a26666a8b4bee06dcd52709d04a95
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-06-26 18:51:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/ca689d629e9db83ebf976583a1565663392f7961', 'message': 'encoding error in file

There is a non-printable character (c2a0) in a comment line, which
in a new Neutron test case causes a StringException. There are
three issues here.

1) Encoding issue in the file.
2) No detection of encoding issues in files.
3) Neutron tests mask the failure detail

This addresses the first issue. Bug 1334798 in Neutron was created
for the last issue. Oslo team is aware of the second issue.

Related bug: #1334798

Change-Id: I8cfa6c93085a26666a8b4bee06dcd52709d04a95

commit_message:
encoding error in file

There is a non-printable character (c2a0) in a comment line, which
in a new Neutron test case causes a StringException. There are
three issues here.

1) Encoding issue in the file.
2) No detection of encoding issues in files.
3) Neutron tests mask the failure detail

This addresses the first issue. Bug 1334798 in Neutron was created
for the last issue. Oslo team is aware of the second issue.

Related-Bug: #1334798

Change-Id: I8cfa6c93085a26666a8b4bee06dcd52709d04a95

commit_message:
Sync loggers and handlers from Horizon upstream

In order to prevent too verbose logging, use recommended
patterns from upstream examples
https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/2014.1.1/openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example

Closes-bug: #1330825

Change-Id: Ie93816388d2bb97d6543c3452398ec15e5c8fd31
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Add validation for agent id of v2/v3 os-agents' update and delete

This patch add validation for agent id for v2/v3 os-agents' update
and delete. Ensure only accept integer for agent id.

Change-Id: I371fe5f3b829c5ed399d85a05e90ffac2c5aa412
Partial-Bug: #1333494

commit_message:
Use config generator rc instead of wrapper script

This commit removes the generate_sample wrapper script and adds an
rc file for the config generator to specify the alternate path.
This makes console messages from the generator tooling point
consistent with what is actually being used. Before because a wrapper
was used error messages would recommend running the incorrect tool.

Change-Id: I0ac792454777af6e3f1d718836031f9a14850229

commit_message:
Update config generator from oslo-incubator

This commit pulls in the latests version of the config generator from
oslo.

Change-Id: I3a2b06dd9ca3285a3d93298ea5727b705f6109e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/48/101248/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Generate sample configuration for your project. # # Aside from the command line flags, it also respects a config file which # should be named oslo.config.generator.rc and be placed in the same directory. # # You can then export the following variables: # TEMPEST_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXTRA_MODULES: list of modules to interrogate for options. # TEMPEST_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXTRA_LIBRARIES: list of libraries to discover. # TEMPEST_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXCLUDED_FILES: list of files to remove from automatic listing. for filename in ${TEMPEST_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXCLUDED_FILES}; do FILES="${FILES[@]/$filename/}" done if [ $? != 0 ] then echo "Can not generate $OUTPUTFILE" exit 1 fi

  added in the future are not; thus this property is used to generalize logic
  in the HDP plug-in.

commit_message:
Upgrades the HDP plug-in to install Hue

Adds a HUE service definition to the set of defined services.  This service
  contains a HUE component defined to be a CLIENT allowing a single instance
  to be configured within a cluster.
Adds the following configuration groups to the set of defined configurations:
  hue-ini - contains configuration options used to build the hue.ini file to
            be deployed to the Hue node
  hue-core-site - contains parameters to add or update within the
                  core-site.xml file to be deployed on relevant nodes
  hue-hdfs-site - contains parameters to add or update within the
                  hdfs-site.xml file to be deployed on relevant nodes
  hue-webhcat-site - contains parameters to add or update within the
                     webhcat-site.xml file to be deployed on relevant nodes
  hue-oozie-site - contains parameters to add or update within the
                   oozie-site.xml file to be deployed on relevant nodes
Adds the HueService class to the set of Service classes. This class implements
  Service to validate that the required services are to be installed in the
  cluster (HIVE, OOZIE, WENHCHAT), ensure the required components are
  installed on the Hue node (HIVE_CLIENT), update relevant site configuration
  files (see above), generate a hue.ini file, install and configure Hue on the
  specified node
Updates the base Service class to include a new property - ambari_managed.
  This property is a Boolean value declaring whether a service is managed by
  Amberi (True) or not (False). The default value is True, since most services
  in the HDP are managed by Ambari. Ambari, Hue, and possibly services to be
  added in the future are not; thus this property is used to generalize logic
  in the HDP plug-in.

Implements: blueprint hdp-plugin-hue-support

Change-Id: Id3ff7a18aa1f65a733c637dc2ea4ce8f988165e4

subject: Do not log 14+ INFO lines on a broken pipe error (eventlet)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-26 00:48:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/ac31249bd5336e5b15df09a1d6fec35d97b4bde7', 'message': 'Do not log 14+ INFO lines on a broken pipe error (eventlet)

Under eventlet if the client disconnects while Keystone is trying
to transmit data, approximately 14 lines of traceback are logged.

This could result in massive logs if done repeatedly; worst case
scenario could include a denial of service due to disk space being
exhausted.

Change-Id: Iaf14c64799daa7539d1bd85cb6c6457380c111d9
Closes-Bug: #1334466

commit_message:
Do not log 14+ INFO lines on a broken pipe error (eventlet)

Under eventlet if the client disconnects while Keystone is trying
to transmit data, approximately 14 lines of traceback are logged.

This could result in massive logs if done repeatedly; worst case
scenario could include a denial of service due to disk space being
exhausted.

Change-Id: Iaf14c64799daa7539d1bd85cb6c6457380c111d9
Closes-Bug: #1334466
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/80/102680/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class HttpProtocol(eventlet.wsgi.HttpProtocol): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(HttpProtocol, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._keystone_logger = log.getLogger('eventlet.wsgi.server') def handle_one_request(self): try: super(HttpProtocol, self).handle_one_request() except socket.error, e: # NOTE(morganfainberg): handle Broken Pipe quietly. Without this # exception handler, it is possible to spam the logs with 14+ # lines of exception data per request if the client disconnects # before Keystone can write data to the FD. if e[0] == 32: self._keystone_logger.debug('Broken Pipe: error writing to ' 'socket.') else: raise log=log.WritableLogger(logger), debug=False, protocol=HttpProtocol)
deleted_lines: log=log.WritableLogger(logger), debug=False)

VMware: refactor get_datastore_ref_and_name

Update vm_util.get_datastore_ref_and_name to use Datastore class,
renamed it to get_datastore, remove vm_util.DSRecord along the way.

partial blueprint vmware-spawn-refactor

commit_message:
Shotgun: make snapshot of entire /var/log

Shootgun uses a fabric.api.get method to download some folder from the
remote host. Unfortunately, this method has a bug and fails when we
trying to download a folder that contains a symlink to another one.

So we need to patch fabric api to prevent us from such falls. The issue
with fabric api is that it recognize all symlinks as a file. As a result
we fails when trying to download a folder (pointed by a symlink)  as
a file.

The patch was proposed to the fabric master branch and can be reviewed
here:

    https://github.com/fabric/fabric/pull/1147

Closes-Bug: #1318514
Closes-Bug: #1323436

Change-Id: Ic2ae889337e5da15bbdf83338b8e8d5d913aeb63

commit_message:
Make sure domains are enabled by default

Domains without an explicit 'enabled' key in the dict will now be
handled in the same way as projects are. This will ensure that
the KVS backend produces the same result as the SQL backend for
assignment.

Change-Id: I3b6d26278329841cfe1be5ce7f67ba6d3569785f
Related-Bug: #1311142

commit_message:
Convert explicit session get/begin to transaction context

Convert the explicit common.sql.get_session() and subsequent
session.begin() to the transaction context manager for Trust
SQL backend.

Change-Id: I52745118782301ef26452063628e16e92e8ee276

commit_message:
Account for differences in Rackspace Cloud Glance

The Rackspace Cloud service catalog has a tenant-scoped URL
for the image service so our client implementation needs to
munge the URL a little to make it work.

Change-Id: Ic5b3702aec8c4ab373dbcf6eb8e6f164d9fd48d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/37/96337/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import urlparse from glanceclient import client as glanceclient def glance(self): if not self._glance: con = self.context endpoint_type = self._get_client_option('glance', 'endpoint_type') endpoint = self.url_for(service_type='image', endpoint_type=endpoint_type, region_name=cfg.CONF.region_name) # Rackspace service catalog includes a tenant scoped glance # endpoint so we have to munge the url a bit glance_url = urlparse.urlparse(endpoint) # remove the tenant and following from the url endpoint = "%s://%s" % (glance_url.scheme, glance_url.hostname) args = { 'auth_url': con.auth_url, 'service_type': 'image', 'project_id': con.tenant, 'token': self.auth_token, 'endpoint_type': endpoint_type, 'ca_file': self._get_client_option('glance', 'ca_file'), 'cert_file': self._get_client_option('glance', 'cert_file'), 'key_file': self._get_client_option('glance', 'key_file'), 'insecure': self._get_client_option('glance', 'insecure') } self._glance = glanceclient.Client('2', endpoint, **args) return self._glance

commit_message:
Update to latest version of pyrax and add Swift support

Change-Id: Ia7f638295d66df7d9df7853f52b5253a74317712
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/58/94658/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._networks = None self._dns = None self._autoscale = None self._lb = None # try and get an end point internal to the DC for faster communication try: return self.pyrax.get_client(name, cfg.CONF.region_name, public=False) # otherwise use the default public one except (pyrax.exceptions.NoEndpointForService, pyrax.exceptions.NoSuchClient): logger.warn(_("Could not find private client for %s. " "Trying public client."), name) return self.pyrax.get_client(name, cfg.CONF.region_name) if not self._autoscale: self._autoscale = self._get_client("autoscale") return self._autoscale if not self._lb: self._lb = self._get_client("load_balancer") return self._lb if not self._dns: self._dns = self._get_client("dns") return self._dns if not self._nova: self._nova = self._get_client("compute") return self._nova if not self._networks: if not self.pyrax: self.__authenticate() # need special handling now since the contextual # pyrax doesn't handle "networks" not being in # the catalog ep = pyrax._get_service_endpoint(self.pyrax, "compute", region=cfg.CONF.region_name) cls = pyrax._client_classes['compute:network'] self._networks = cls(self.pyrax, region_name=cfg.CONF.region_name, management_url=ep) return self._networks def swift(self): # Rackspace doesn't include object-store in the default catalog # for "reasons". The pyrax client takes care of this, but it # returns a wrapper over the upstream python-swiftclient so we # unwrap here and things just work if not self._swift: self._swift = self._get_client("object_store").connection return self._swift def __authenticate(self): """Create an authenticated client context.""" self.pyrax = pyrax.create_context("rackspace") self.pyrax.auth_endpoint = self.context.auth_url logger.info(_("Authenticating username: %s") % tenant = self.context.tenant_id tenant_name = self.context.tenant self.pyrax.auth_with_token(self.context.auth_token, tenant_id=tenant, tenant_name=tenant_name) if not self.pyrax.authenticated: logger.warn(_("Pyrax Authentication Failed.")) raise exception.AuthorizationFailure() logger.info(_("User %s authenticated successfully."), self.context.username)
deleted_lines: return self.pyrax.get(name) return self._get_client("autoscale") def cloud_db(self): """Rackspace cloud database client.""" return self._get_client("database") return self._get_client("load_balancer") return self._get_client("dns") if service_type is not "compute": raise ValueError(_("service_type should be compute.")) return self._get_client(service_type) return self._get_client("network") def __authenticate(self): pyrax.set_setting("identity_type", "keystone") pyrax.set_setting("auth_endpoint", self.context.auth_url) logger.info(_("Authenticating username:%s") % self.pyrax = pyrax.auth_with_token(self.context.auth_token, tenant_id=self.context.tenant_id, tenant_name=self.context.tenant, region=(cfg.CONF.region_name or None)) if not self.pyrax: raise exception.AuthorizationFailure("No services available.") logger.info(_("User %s authenticated successfully.") % self.context.username)

subject: Implemented S3 multi-part upload functionality
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-02 07:31:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/2691eeff18cef56196e9997ee9a6a2c5b881f4fa', 'message': "Implementation S3 multi-part upload functionality

Currently glance is using only a single put object REST API to store
an object to S3 servers even if it's a large object.

If glance can use an S3 MultiPart Upload REST API for the large objects
in future release as Amazon recommends it for the large object to be
uploaded, it's very useful for the customers and a good thing for AWS
and other S3 servers.

Depending on the new parameters below, the behavior keeps as currectly
doing(single object put) if the object size is less than
's3_store_large_object_size'.
If the size is greater than the parameter, the target object will be
divided by 's3_store_large_object_chunk_size' and into a several chunked
objects and each chunked object will be uploaded to S3 server in
a multi-thread manner in parallel.

Two parameters below will be added.

[/etc/glance/glance-api.conf]
s3_store_large_object_size = 5120

s3_store_large_object_chunk_size = 10

Besides, this change is required a boto python library to be updated.
To able to handle a multipart upload, 'upload_part_from_file' method
in a boto library needs to be updated to return 'key' object.

This change is already reported and fixed into boto develop branch
and it's available from boto 2.12.0 and later.
If the next openstack uses this version of boto(2.12.0 and later),
there is nothing to do for this part.

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2013-10-03 07:09:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/312fd35b7cfbba7e39a936d6592f9a09aa6ed035', 'message': "Implementation S3 multi-part upload functionality

Currently glance is using only a single put object REST API to store
an object to S3 servers even if it's a large object.

This is an implementation for glance to be able to use an S3 MultiPart
Upload REST API for the large objects to be uploaded as AWS recommends
it. It would be very useful for the customers and a good thing for AWS
and other S3 compatibility servers.

Depending on the new parameters below, the behavior keeps as currectly
doing(single object put) if the object size is less than
's3_store_large_object_size'.
If the size is greater than the parameter, the target object will be
divided by 's3_store_large_object_chunk_size' and into a several chunked
objects and each chunked object will be uploaded to S3 server in
a multi-thread manner in parallel.

Two parameters below will be added.

[/etc/glance/glance-api.conf]
s3_store_large_object_size = 5120

s3_store_large_object_chunk_size = 10

Besides, this change is required a boto python library to be updated.
To able to handle a multipart upload, 'upload_part_from_file' method
in a boto library needs to be updated to return 'key' object.

This boto change is already reported and fixed into boto develop
branch and it's available from boto 2.12.0 and later.
If the next openstack uses this version of boto(2.12.0 and later),
there is nothing to do for this part.

Implements: blueprint s3-multi-part-upload
Change-Id: I36e28e7944e57cd7ac05e46afac461ec10245c68
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2013-10-10 08:55:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/9c132ac969458436ed201c46168d4de125d1d0fb', 'message': 'Implementation S3 multi-part upload functionality
